source_file: A_80_6 (SECT. 3)_ADD.3_CLUSTER II_FASCICLE ADVANCE UNEDITED COPY FOR ACABQ.json

content.text: A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024

children.text: Overall orientation
Mandates and background

The Panel of Experts on Libya is responsible for monitoring the implementation of the arms embargo, asset freeze, travel ban and measures in relation to attempts to illicitly export petroleum, and for providing information relevant to the potential designation of individuals and entities. The mandate derives from the priorities established in relevant Security Council resolutions, including resolutions 1973 (2011), 2009 (2011) and 2017 (2011), and renewed by its subsequent resolutions, including, most recently, 2769 (2025). The sanctions regime is aimed at preventing and containing threats to the peace, security and stability of Libya, including obstructing or undermining the successful completion of the political transition. In its resolution 2733 (2024), the Council requested the Secretary-General to report on the implementation of the arms embargo on the high seas off the coast of Libya within 6 months and 11 months of the adoption of the resolution. The Secretary-General submitted his first report on 26 November 2024 (S/2024/858), while the second report was submitted on 25 April 2025 (S/2025/257).

In its resolution 2769 (2025), the Security Council decided to allow the frozen cash reserves of the Libyan Investment Authority (LIA) to be invested in low-risk time deposits and in fixed financial instruments, subject to a notification and approval procedure by the Sanctions Committee concerning Libya, and requested the Panel of Experts to assess the effect and performance of these investments in their annual final reports.
Programme of work
Objective

The objective, to which this mission contributes, is to ensure the full implementation of the sanctions regime concerning Libya, which includes an arms embargo, an asset freeze, a travel ban and measures in relation to attempts to illicitly export petroleum.
Strategy and external factors for 2026

To contribute to the objective, the Panel of Experts will provide updated information to the Security Council and to the Security Council Committee established pursuant to resolution 1970 (2011) concerning Libya, including an assessment of the performance of reinvestment of the LIA’s frozen cash reserves.
The above-mentioned work is expected to result in an enhanced capacity of the Security Council and the Committee to take follow-up action on alleged violations of the sanctions regime.

With regard to cooperation with other entities, in the context of information-sharing, the Panel of Experts cooperates with, among others, Member States and the European Union, in particular its military operation in the Mediterranean.

With regard to inter-agency coordination and liaison, the Panel of Experts cooperates with the United Nations Support Mission in Libya, the Focal Point for Delisting to support the review of petitioners’ requests to be removed from the Committee’s sanctions list, and other sanctions monitoring teams, groups and panels, as appropriate. In the context of safety, security and logistics, the Panel cooperates with the Department of Safety and Security and UNDP.
With regard to the external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the following planning assumptions:
(a)	Member States comply with the resolutions of the Security Council and cooperate with the Panel of Experts;
(b)	The security situation allows the Panel of Experts to conduct missions in the field.
(c) 	Proposals for investment and reinvestment of LIA’s frozen cash reserves are submitted.
Programme performance in 2024
Enhanced capacity of the Security Council and the Committee to address violations of the arms embargo

In its final report (S/2024/914), the Panel of Experts highlighted the unprecedented influence of armed groups over State institutions in western and eastern Libya. The Panel further recommended possible actions that could enable the reinvestment of the LIA’s frozen assets as requested by the Council. The Panel also reported on continued violations of the arms embargo, on illicit fuel smuggling by armed groups, and on human trafficking and migrant smuggling through Libyan territory involving Libyan armed actors. The Panel recommended clarifying the scope of the arms embargo and that additional individuals who met the sanctions designation criteria be considered for listing.
Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 18).
Table 18 – Performance measure

table_content.text: Security Council and Committee continued to receive information on instances of non-compliance with the arms embargo and considered follow-up action to address violations of the arms embargo

Security Council and Committee received information on instances of non-compliance with the arms embargo and considered follow-up action on reported arms embargo violations, and possible listings of individuals and entities

Security Council and Committee received information on instances of non-compliance with the assets freeze and the arms embargo, and on the possibility of reinvestment of the LIA’s frozen assets, and considered follow-up action

children.text: Planned result for 2026
Enhanced capacity of the Security Council and the Committee to address non-compliance with the assets freeze and the arms embargo – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

In 2024, the work of the Panel contributed to the implementation of this sanctions regime, meeting the planned target. The Panel reported on unprecedented levels of influence over State institutions exercised by armed groups in Libya, international human trafficking and smuggling networks which utilized Libyan territory as a transit hub, on the violations of international humanitarian and human rights law, terrorist elements active in southern Libya, and on possible reinvestment of the LIA’s frozen assets. This enabled the Security Council and the Committee to consider follow-up action.
Lessons learned and planned change

The lesson for the Panel was the need for improved coordination and information-sharing with the Government of Libya, relevant international bodies and regional actors. In applying the lesson, the Panel will continue to enhance information exchange and improve cooperation among relevant stakeholders.
Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see table 19).
Table 19 – Performance measure

table_content.text: Security Council and Committee received information on instances of non-compliance with the arms embargo from the Panel of Experts and considered follow-up action
On the basis of information provided by the Panel of Experts, the Security Council and Committee took follow-up action on reported arms embargo violations, including considering listings

On the basis of information provided by the Panel of Experts, the Security Council and Committee took follow-up action on reported on non-compliance with the assets freeze and the arms embargo, and allowed the possibility of reinvestment of certain LIA frozen assets

Based on the Panel of Experts’ information, Security Council and Committee take follow-up action on reported violations of the arms embargo, international humanitarian and human rights laws, and human rights abuses, including considering listings

Based on the Panel of Experts’ information, Security Council and Committee take follow-up action on non-compliance with the assets freeze and the arms embargo, violations of international humanitarian and human rights laws, and human rights abuses, including considering listings, and on possible   reinvestment of LIA’s frozen assets

content.text: B.	Proposed post and non-post resource requirements for 2026

children.text: Resource requirements (regular budget) – Table 21 – Financial resources – (Thousands of United States dollars)
Table 22 – Human resources
a	Other level, unless otherwise stated.

The proposed resource requirements for the Panel of Experts for 2026 amount to $1,549,700 (net of staff assessment) and would provide for salaries and common staff costs ($275,400) for the continuation of two posts (1 P-3 and 1 General Service (Other level)) to provide substantive, administrative and security support in relation to the sanctions regime, and operational costs ($1,274,300) comprising expert fees ($796,700) and travel ($333,800) of the six experts, official travel of staff ($16,800) and other operational and logistical support requirements, including the rental of premises, rental of vehicles, communications and information technology services and other supplies, services and equipment ($127,000).

For 2026, no change is proposed to the number and level of posts for the mission. A vacancy rate of zero per cent has been applied to the staff costs for international staff, while a rate of 50 per cent has been applied for national staff, on the basis of the average vacancy rate in 2024 and the actual vacancy rate in March 2025 respectively.

The increase in the requirements for 2026 compared with the appropriation for 2025 is attributable primarily to higher requirements for civilian personnel, owing to the application of a lower vacancy rate for international staff compared with the rate of 45.8 per cent applied in 2025 and higher estimates for common staff costs, as well as increased requirements for expert fees. The increase is offset in part by lower requirements for telecommunications and network services and the application of latest ICT standard rates.
